strategic_profile.executive_summary: Washington University in St. Louis is a premier private research institution renowned for its Collegiate Gothic architecture, world-class medical facilities, and a collaborative academic culture that spans nine specialized schools. It is widely recognized for balancing high-intensity research output with a strong emphasis on undergraduate teaching and student well-being.

analyst_takeaways.insight: Acceptance rates have tightened significantly, reaching a historic low of approximately 12% for the Class of 2028, down from roughly 15-16% in recent years.
analyst_takeaways.implication: Applicants should utilize Early Decision (ED I or ED II) pathways, which typically account for about 60% of the incoming class, to maximize admission chances.

analyst_takeaways.insight: The university transitioned to a need-blind admissions policy for all domestic applicants in 2021, supported by a multi-billion dollar endowment.
analyst_takeaways.implication: This removes financial barriers for high-talent, low-income students, increasing the diversity and competitiveness of the applicant pool.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: The social atmosphere is characterized as 'collaborative without being cutthroat,' with over 400 student organizations and a strong emphasis on community engagement through the Gephardt Institute.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: As a multimodal campus, WashU provides U-Passes for free regional transit (MetroLink/MetroBus) and has integrated the Centennial Greenway trail, reducing reliance on cars and fostering a pedestrian-friendly environment adjacent to Forest Park.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: With an annual research budget exceeding $900 million and deep ties to the Washington University Medical Center, students have early access to high-impact clinical and technical research, particularly in biotechnology and public health.

gpa.notes: 86% of students in the Class of 2028 ranked in the top 10% of their high school class. Admissions emphasizes rigor and GPA as critical factors.

testing.policy_note: Test-optional for the Class of 2028, but returning to required testing for the Class of 2030 (Fall 2026 entry).

men.note: Represents 47% of the enrolling Class of 2028.

women.note: Represents 53% of the enrolling Class of 2028.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Class of 2029 is the second-largest in university history.

colleges.name: College of Arts & Sciences
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strongest fit for students demonstrating 'intellectual spark' and interdisciplinary curiosity; pre-med applicants should emphasize research and community service.
colleges.housing_profile: Primarily housed in the South 40 residential colleges; known for a mix of traditional and modern suites.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious polymaths and high-achieving pre-professional students

colleges.name: Olin Business School
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Requires a strong quantitative background; Calculus is essential.
colleges.housing_profile: South 40 suites for underclassmen; many juniors and seniors live in the 'Village'.

colleges.name: McKelvey School of Engineering
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Prioritize high-level Math and Science. Highlight collaborative problem-solving skills.
colleges.housing_profile: Access to specialized makerspaces and collaborative study lounges.

minors_certificates: Anthropology: Global Health and Environment Minor
Data Science in the Humanities Minor

supplemental_requirements.details: One 200-word response regarding academic interest and division choice.
One 250-word response to one of two prompts.
90-second optional video to share personal qualities.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: Emphasis on 'By Name & Story' philosophy and collaborative mindset.

major_selection_tactics: Apply to the College of Arts & Sciences as 'Undeclared' for maximum flexibility.
Utilize the Beyond Boundaries program as a 'no-risk' application add-on.
Apply to the McKelvey School of Engineering only if you have high-level math/physics scores.
strategy_tactics.alternate_major_strategy: If targeting a highly competitive major like BME or Finance, consider applying to a related major in Arts & Sciences and transferring internally later.

what_it_takes: High academic statistics with typical SAT scores in the 1500-1570 range
Strong preference for Early Decision (ED1) to maximize admit odds
Evidence of a collaborative rather than competitive mindset
essay_tips: Mention specific programs like 'Ampersand Courses' or 'Beyond Boundaries'
Emphasize your connection to the St. Louis community ('In St. Louis, For St. Louis')
Write with an authentic personal voice rather than a formal academic tone
red_flags: Generic essays that could apply to any top-tier research university
Treating the application as a backup for Ivy League schools

scholarships.name: WashU Pledge
scholarships.amount: Full tuition, fees, room, and board

ap_policy.general_rule: Scores of 4 or 5 are generally required to earn credit
ap_policy.usage: Max 15 units of total pre-matriculation credit

ib_policy.general_rule: Credit granted for Higher Level (HL) exams only, scores 5-7

transfer_articulation.restrictions: 60-unit transfer cap for most undergraduate schools

essay_prompts.prompt: Please tell us what you are interested in studying at college and why. Undecided about your academic interest(s)? Don't worry—tell us what excites you about the academic division you selected. Remember that all of our first-year students enter officially 'undeclared' and work closely with their team of academic advisors to discover their academic passions.
WashU supports engagement in the St. Louis community by considering the university as 'In St. Louis, For St. Louis.' What is a community you are a part of and your place or impact within it?
essay_prompts.note: Optional - choose one of two options

essay_prompts.prompt: WashU strives to know every undergraduate student 'By Name & Story.' How have your life experiences shaped your story?
essay_prompts.note: Optional - choose one of two options

essay_prompts.prompt: Tell us about something that really sparks your intellectual curiosity and why.
brainstorming_questions: Thinking about the moment you first encountered this intellectual spark, can you describe the specific sensory details or the unexpected place where this curiosity ignited?
When this particular topic or idea captured your attention, what was the very first 'why' that bubbled up inside you, and how did that initial question evolve?
Beyond the surface level, what are the underlying assumptions or puzzles within this area of curiosity that you find yourself compelled to unravel or challenge?
Can you recall a time when pursuing this intellectual spark led you down an unplanned path or to an unexpected discovery, and what did that detour reveal about your learning process?
If you could sit down with someone who *doesn't* understand why this sparks your curiosity, what's the one most essential aspect or hidden beauty of it that you'd strive to convey to them?
